Sharon Post 2

 25 Aug 2017

Perrotta. C., Featherstone. G., Aston. H. & Houghton. E. (2013). Game-based Learning: Latest Evidence and Future Directions (NFER Research Programme: Innovation in Education). Slough: NFER.

This article details a literature review conducted by UK’s National Foundation for Educational Research (NFER). The aim of the literature review was to provide educators with practical and non-academic insights into game-based learning.

Perrotta, Featherstone, Aston and Houghton (2013) found that the literature reviewed supports the idea that game-based learning can improve engagement and student motivation.

The authors found that video games can provide authentic virtual worlds which contribute to the usefulness of the learning experience. These games can provide a vehicle for real world challenges and learning outcomes which, the authors contend, are more useful than “‘outdated’ forms of knowledge acquired through traditional schooling” (p.6). The authors use the words ‘ video games’ and ‘computer games’ interchangeably and state that this format allows students to experience academic content through “interaction and simulation” (p.6), arguably supporting the view that real world learning can occur through this virtual medium.

The use of computer games to provide authentic virtual worlds can be seen as an opportunity for teachers to use the internet in a more creative way, somewhat alleviating Reeves, Herrington & Oliver’s (2002) concerns that teachers are not using the internet to its full potential.

Finally, Perrotta et al make the following recommendations to teachers and senior school leaders about the implications of the review for teachers and schools:

  • Games should be integrated into teaching with clear pedagogical intention.
  • All academic content and learning activities should be contained within the game context and not as an addition to the use of the game.
  • Teachers and learners’ roles in the game should be carefully planned. The best practice is for teachers to take on mediatory or facilitative roles, to ensure rules are followed and to provide guidance when needed.
  • Teachers are encouraged to keep game like components such as leaderboards and badges in the experiences they create, as those components enhance the learning for students.

This review is helpful to secondary school teachers’ context as it distils select academic literature published between 2006 and 2013 into a handful of recommendations and practical take-home points. The practical nature of the recommendations allows teachers to apply recent academic research into their pedagogical practices without having to undertake onerous research themselves. However, Perrotta et al have only reviewed 31 articles out of a possible 485, therefore scope exists for further research on the topic to be carried out by teachers interested in game-based learning.

References for this post:

Perrotta. C., Featherstone. G., Aston. H. & Houghton. E. (2013). Game-based Learning: Latest Evidence and Future Directions (NFER Research Programme: Innovation in Education). Slough: NFER.

Reeves, T., Herrington, J. & Oliver, R. (2002) Authentic activities and online learning. Proceedings of HERDSA 2002, pp.562-567.
